title: Probability that a quadratic equation with random coefficients has real roots [duplicate]
body:
This question already has answers here : Probability that a quadratic polynomial with random coefficients has real roots (6 answers) Closed 5 years ago . Consider quadratic equations $Ax^2 + Bx + C = 0$ in which $A$ , $B$ , and $C$ are
  independently distributed $\mathsf{Unif}(0,1)$ . What is the probability that the roots of such an equation are real? This problem is from  Chapter 3 of Rice: Mathematical Statistics and Data Analysis (editions 1 through 3). Until recent printings of 3e, the incorrect answer 1/9 was given for this problem. However, Horton (2015) http://www3.amherst.edu/~nhorton/precursors/precursors.pdf points out that the correct answer is slightly above 1/4, as can be verified by a simple simulation. (Horton and his colleagues are concerned with elements of an undergraduate curriculum to prepare students in the mathematical sciences to cope with modern data science.) In a somewhat more practical setting, one might consider a discrete version of this problem.
A program that produces random drill problems on quadratic equations $Ax^2 + Bx + C = 0,$ selects values for $A, B,$ and $C$ at random and independently from among the ten equally likely values $0.1, 0.2, \dots, 1.0$ . What proportion of such equations have real roots? And what proportion have only one root? The initial Answer sketches the exact analytic solution of the original problem and shows numerical and graphical results from simulation. A simulated result for the discrete version is also shown. Additional answers using other methods or discussing related topics are welcome.

title: Most wanted reproducible results in computational algebra

I hope that making such a list of suggested experiments to reproduce will be useful to those interested in checking them twice ;-). For example, one could submit their findings to a journal like ReScience which "targets computational research and encourages the explicit replication of already published research, promoting new and open-source implementations in order to ensure that the original research is reproducible". $$\int_0^{\int_0^\ldots \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} \ \mathrm{d}x} \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} \ \mathrm{d}x$$

title: Convergence in probability implies convergence in distribution of random variables
body: I am studying Professor Rick Durrett's book "Probability: Theory and Examples" and would greatly appreciate feedback on the validity of my proof. Claim: If $X_n$ converges to $X$ in probability, then $X_n$ converges weakly to $X$. Definitions: $X_n\to X$ in probability means for every $\epsilon>0$, $P(|X_n-X|>\epsilon)\to 0$ as $n\to\infty$. Given a sequence of distribution functions $F_n$, $F_n\to F$ weakly (also known as convergence in distribution) means $F_n(y)\to F(y)$ for all points $y$ that are continuity points of $F$. Given a sequence of random variables $X_n$ with $F_n$ the distribution function of each $X_n$, $X_n\to X$ weakly means $F_n\to F$ weakly. Proof: Let $g$ be a continuous, bounded function. Recall that $X_n\to X$ in probability implies that for every subsequence $X_{n(m)}$, there exists a convergent sub-subsequence $X_{n(m_k)}$ so that $X_{n(m_k)}\to X$ almost surely, and hence $g(X_{n(m_k)})\to g(X)$ almost surely. Then $Eg(X_{n(m_k)})\to Eg(X)$ by the dominated convergence theorem. Since the subsequence $X_{n(m)}$ was arbitrary, we have $Eg(X_n)\to Eg(X)$. Further, since $g$ was arbitrary, $X_n\to X$ weakly. Thanks a bunch in advance for the feedback! Facts I used: $X_n\to X$ in probability iff for every subsequence of random variables $X_{n(m)}$, there exists a further subsequence $X_{n(m_k)}$ such that $X_{n(m_k)}\to X$ almost surely. If $y_n$ is a sequence of elements in a topological space such that for every subsequence $y_{n(m)}$, there exists a further subsequence $y_{n(m_k)}\to y$, then $y_n\to y$. $X_n\to X$ weakly iff for every bounded continuous function $g$ we have $Eg(X_n)\to Eg(X)$.
